comments.body: this is needed because previous plots are not properly cleaned up. I'm not sure if that's the best way to do it, though.

Can you open an issue with steps to repro? would help get it fixed elsewhere
if it needs to be.

well... `plt.close` is used throughout the test module; it seems to me that `_check_plot_works` serves the same purpose but it saves the plot to a temporary file in order to cleanup. 

BTW: Matplotlib has a cleanup decorator that get rid of side effects in test code ( http://matplotlib.org/devel/testing.html )

comments.body: This seems like it could be a separate test.
It can, but I think it is better to bundle series of test to avoid any inconsistencies between each plots. As each check can be skipped by passing `None`, the test can be used for almost all cases.

I think there's a way to reset the warnings filter: https://docs.python.org/2/library/warnings.html

I've never done it properly, whenever I'm testing I'll just reset the global `__warningregistry__` to `{}`.
